instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green light, No power
threads.message:
Board was originally slightly liquid damaged.
PPBUS: 12.58 volts
3V42: 3.42

SMC reset chip and entire top edge of board looked awful so replaced many burned components including <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>. Still get 3.42 volts on PP3V42 and 12.58 volts on PPBUS despite no green light. Rest of board looks clean <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL>: 0 volts Adapter Sense with KNOWN GOOD DC in board is also 0 volts (?). What do I check for next?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green light, No power
threads.message: Resistance to GND on 3V42? If below 18K then MCP is dead.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green light, No power
threads.message: Ok will check tomorrow I kinda thought that the moment I opened it lol I hate 2010 13‚Äùs

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green light, No power
threads.message: Resistance to ground 4.6K so dead MCP the end. Thanks anyway Duke!
